explanation:
Any for-loop executed while MHD_get_rq_dauth_params_ runs must be inspected for MISRA well-formedness. That includes loops inside functions called directly or indirectly and any types/objects those functions manipulate. Reasons: 
- find_auth_rq_header_: called directly; may contain for-loops whose counters/side-effects would run in the context of the target function. 
- MHD_connection_alloc_memory_: called directly to allocate dauth; may contain loops and calls other pool allocators. 
- MHD_pool_try_alloc, MHD_pool_reallocate, MHD_pool_allocate: direct callees of MHD_connection_alloc_memory_; their for-loops (if any) are executed as part of allocation called by the target function and must be checked. 
- parse_dauth_params: called directly to parse the header; may contain for-loops and modifies *dauth (objects used by the caller), so its loops must be checked for loop-counter usage and side-effects. 
- get_rq_dauth_algo, get_rq_dauth_qop: callees of parse_dauth_params; inspect for-loops they contain. 
- MHD_DLOG: logging call used in error branches; its implementation may contain loops (formatting, buffering) that execute during the target function. 
- mhd_assert: assertion macro/function invoked at start; include to confirm it does not hide loops/side effects. 
- struct MHD_Connection, struct MHD_RqDAuth, struct _MHD_str_w_len: definitions of these types are needed to see which objects (fields) are read or written by the target and by callees — to determine whether loop conditions/clauses incorrectly use or modify objects that are updated in loop bodies.

Inspecting the source of these symbols (direct callees and their callees plus the relevant type definitions) gives a complete view of any for-loops that execute while MHD_get_rq_dauth_params_ runs and whether they meet the MISRA for-loop requirements.
